projectDesc.p: "De Muliere Mala" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Prologus de mala muliere
app.rdg: Prologue

app.lem: Quisquis male mulieris artes malas scire queris,
app.rdg: May you, who seek to know the wicked tricks of Woman,

app.lem: Que subscripsi coacerua, lege disce, mente serua.
app.rdg: Read, learn, and keep in mind the the verses written below.

app.lem: Si uis tandem felix esse, haec ut legas est necesse.
app.rdg: Indeed, if you wish to be happy, it is necessary that you read these words.

app.lem: Hic addisces, hic uidebis, quid dimittes, quid tenebis.
app.rdg: Here you will learn and see what you will dismiss and what you will remember.

app.lem: Hic Caribdis atque Sille patent antra, Syrtes mille,
app.rdg:
Here lie open the caves of Scylla and Charybdis, along with a thousand Sirtes:
The Gulf of Sirte, infamous for its hazardous sandbanks, is located on the northern coast of Libya.

app.lem: Hic describo Cyrcen lenam, absorbentemque balenam.
app.rdg:
Here I describe whorish Circe and the all-consuming whale.
Perhaps a reference to Jonah 1.17.

app.lem: Que ne formides in mari, naui uectus salutari,
app.rdg: So that you will not fear these threats at sea, while you sail in a salutary ship,

app.lem: Deum ama, fuge scortum. Castitatis tene portum.
app.rdg: You should love God, flee harlotry, and seek the port of chastity.

app.lem:
[De mala muliere]
While this rubric is not present in the MS, I have marked it since the prologue ends and the main body begins here.
app.rdg: [On the Wicked Woman]

app.lem: Uersus et euersus in me, dum fabrico uersus,
app.rdg: While I compose my verses, I twist and turn within my mind.

app.lem: Non ualeo fari, non scribere, non meditari,
app.rdg: I can barely speak, write, and think:

app.lem: Ut fatear uerum, que sit feritas mulierum.
app.rdg: How can I ever tell the entire truth about the savagery of women?

app.lem: Sed licet ad uotum nequeam describere totum,
app.rdg: Nevertheless, although I cannot describe it all, as I wish to,

app.lem: Quicquid de Scilla feritatis habundat in illa,

app.rdg: I shall speak a little – if the Muses come to my aid –

app.lem: Dicam pauca tamen, si det michi musa iuuamen.

app.rdg:
About that Scyllan beastliness that abounds in Woman.
There are two Scyllas mentioned in the poem – the aquatic monster Scylla (Hom. Od. 12.111-150) and Scylla, princess of Megara (Ov. Met. 8.6-151). In this case, the term ‘feritatis’ (‘[of] beastliness’) evokes the former rather than the latter.

app.lem: Prestat in orbe feris cunctis feritas mulieris,
app.rdg: The savagery of Woman exceeds that of all the beasts in the world;

app.lem: Tygri predoni prestat, rapidoque leoni;
app.rdg:
It puts to shame the preying tiger and swift-footed lion.
‘Puts to shame’ is an idiomatic translation of ‘prestat’ and its dative object; more literally, ‘The savagery of Woman exceeds that of the preying tiger and the swift-footed lion’.

app.lem: Uincitur istarum feritas, rabiesque ferarum,
app.rdg: On the one hand, the savagery of these creatures and the madness of all other beasts can be conquered,

app.lem:
Haeque
As is expected with medieval manuscripts, the ‘ae’ digraph is confused with the letter ‘e’ throughout. I have preserved the [mis]spellings of the manuscript. In this case ‘ae’ is used correctly, but often it is not (cf. line 78).
pati discunt homines illosque tremiscunt.
app.rdg: As they learn to bear the yoke and tremble at men.

app.lem: Femina uero feris truculencior una seueris,
app.rdg: On the other hand, Woman alone is more ferocious than the fiercest beasts:

app.lem: Numquam pacatur, nulla racione domatur,
app.rdg: She is never appeased, and can in no way be tamed.

app.lem: Non homini cedit, non sponte fauet nec obedit,
app.rdg: She does not yield to Man, nor favour him, nor obey him.

app.lem: Non ad iter recti ualet ullo uerbere flecti.
app.rdg: She cannot be led to the right path with beatings;

app.lem: Quo uexata magis fuerit mala femina plagis,
app.rdg: In fact, the more a wicked woman is harried by blows,

app.lem: Tanto maiorem studet exercere furorem.
app.rdg: The greater fury she strives to exhibit.

app.lem: Nec mala desistit fieri, stimuloque resistit.
app.rdg: Moreover, she does not cease becoming evil, but instead resists the spur.

app.lem: Quisquis Samsonem considerat et Salomonem,
app.rdg: Whoever considers the cases of Samson and Solomon,

app.lem: Et reliquos multos mulieris amore sopitos
app.rdg: And the many others brought to eternal rest by love of a woman,

app.lem: Discet et intendet, mirabitur et reprehendet
app.rdg: Will learn, notice, criticise and marvel at

app.lem: Exemplis ueris portenta male mulieris.
app.rdg: The real-life precursors of my ‘wicked woman’.

app.lem: Femina flamma furens, sed flammis acrius urens
app.rdg: Woman, flaming mad, is singed all the more sharply by her own flames.

app.lem: Totum concussit mundum, succendit, et ussit.
app.rdg: She shakes up the whole world, lights it on fire, and burns it down.

app.lem: Hec est cunctorum caput, et scintilla malorum,
app.rdg: She is the beginning and spark of all evils,

app.lem: Orbis que metas semper facit inrequietas.
app.rdg: For she troubles the ends of the earth for eternity.

app.lem: O mala scintilla: quisquis succenditur illa,
app.rdg: O wicked spark: whoever is set alight by Woman

app.lem: Ille nec indigne misero consumitur igne,
app.rdg: is deservedly consumed by a wretched fire,

app.lem: Nec nisi diuina ualet extingui medicina.
app.rdg: which cannot be extinguished unless by some divine remedy.

app.lem: Haec hominem primum de celso trusit in imum,
app.rdg: It was Woman who first cast Man down from up high,

app.lem: Intulit et penam mundo, mortisque catenam.
app.rdg: bringing punishment and the chain of death to the world.

app.lem: Sponsum, serpentem, uitam, genus, Omnipotentem,
app.rdg: She betrayed her husband, welcomed the serpent, spurned life,

app.lem: Prodidit, admisit, spreuit, uiciauit, omisit.
app.rdg:
injured mankind, and lost the All-Powerful.
In the original Latin, this sentence is constructed using two asyndetic verses: ‘Her husband, the serpent, life, mankind, and the All-Powerful / she betrayed, welcomed, spurned, injured, and lost.’

app.lem: Et quis eam laudet? Quicquid male cogitat audet,
app.rdg: And who shall praise her? She dares to perform whatever evil she thinks up,

app.lem: Et cupit expleri rem, qua rea possit haberi.
app.rdg: and yearns to commit some act, so that she will be perceived as guilty.

app.lem: Nil fugit incestum, cupit omne quod est inhonestum,
app.rdg: In addition, she shuns nothing which is taboo, but wants everything which is dishonourable.

app.lem: Quicquid agit secum, fas siue nefas, putat equum.
app.rdg: She considers all her plans to be just, whether they be right or wrong.

app.lem: Femina terrarum confusio, mors animarum,
app.rdg: Woman is the disorder of lands and the death of souls:

app.lem: Ut mundo late resonet scelerum nouitate,
app.rdg: she is heard far and wide throughout the world due to the strangeness of her sins.

app.lem: Nil dubium dubitat, nichil euitabile uitat,
app.rdg: She does not doubt that which is doubtful, nor avoid that which is avoidable,

app.lem: Nil intemptatum sinit, it scelus omne patratum,
app.rdg: but leaves nothing untried, and commits every sin,

app.lem: Ad causas quasque confundens fasque nefasque.
app.rdg: confusing right and wrong for her own purposes.

app.lem: Quo magis obscenum scelus est, magis huic fit amenum,
app.rdg: The more obscene a crime is, the more pleasant it seems to her;

app.lem: Quo magis horrendum, magis hoc putat esse colendum.
app.rdg: the more terrible a sin, the greater the glory she places upon it.

app.lem: Imperium, sensum, uires, fastidia, censum,
app.rdg: She obtains power, weakens perception, diminishes strength,

app.lem: Optinet, emollit, minuit, generat, male tollit.
app.rdg:
creates annoyance, and exhausts wealth.
See n. 4.

app.lem: Femina tormentum iuuenum, mortis monimentum,
app.rdg: Indeed, Woman is a torment for young men and a reminder of death:

app.lem: Mortem Samsoni dedit, interitum Salomoni.
app.rdg: she brought about Samson’s demise and Solomon’s end.

app.lem: Femina priuauit pietatis robore Dauid,
app.rdg: She also deprived David of the strength of his piety,

app.lem: Quando per inuidiam iugulari fecit Uriam
app.rdg:
when he ordered Uriah’s murder out of lustful envy.
2 Samuel 11:5-27. David places Uriah at the front lines of a dangerous battle so as to eliminate him, as he was enamoured with Uriah’s wife, Bathsheba.

app.lem: Coniuge pro pulchra multi subiere sepulcra.
app.rdg: Many have gone to their graves due to their beautiful wives.

app.lem: Femina plena malis, faera, pessima, demonialis,
app.rdg: Woman is full of evils, wild, demonic, the worst of all creatures.

app.lem: Priuauit uita Naboth, pro uitae cupita:
app.rdg:
She took away Naboth’s life to obtain his vineyard;
1 Kings 21:2-15. Jezebel has Naboth killed so that her husband, King Ahab, can have Naboth’s vineyard.

app.lem: Causa necis subitae sunt res plerumque cupite.
app.rdg: she murders on sudden impulses, and especially out of greed.

app.lem: Femina mors mundi, mala femina fabula mundi.
app.rdg: Indeed, Woman is the death of the world, and a wicked woman is its scandal.

app.lem: Exicium, reges, insontes, federa, leges,
app.rdg: She brings destruction, murders kings, slaughters innocents,

app.lem: Attulit, orbauit, strauit, soluit, uiolauit.
app.rdg:
unbinds treaties, and violates laws.
See n. 4.

app.lem: Illa Ioseph iustum Veneris non ignibus ustum,
app.rdg: She saw to it that Joseph, who remained unburnt by the fires of Venus,

app.lem: Carcere dampnari fecit ferroque ligari.
app.rdg: was condemned to prison and bound in iron chains.

app.lem: Hec etiam plena rabie truculenta leena
app.rdg:
Similarly, that aggressive whore,
Salome.
filled with madness,

app.lem: Fecit ut athletam Domini magnumque prophetam
app.rdg: Rex ferus artaret uinclis, gladioque necaret,

app.lem: Et tulit in disco caput illius, unde tremisco.
app.rdg: persuaded the savage king to bind in chains

app.lem: and kill the champion of the Lord, that great prophet:
app.rdg:
then she carried his head on a platter. How I tremble at this!
Literally ‘at which I tremble’.

app.lem: Fabula Grecorum de libris promit eorum
app.rdg: The books of the Greeks tell of

app.lem: Quomodo regina Cretensis, lege ferina,
app.rdg:
How the Cretan queen,
Pasiphaë.
following the customs of beasts,

app.lem: Carnis ob ardorem nimium, mentisque furorem,
app.rdg: Driven by mental madness and an excess of carnal lust,

app.lem: Taurum decipit niueum, coituque recepit
app.rdg: Deceived a snow-white bull and copulated with him,

app.lem: Et peperit natum, taurumque uirumque c[r]eatum:
app.rdg: Eventually giving birth to a son who was half man and half bull.

app.lem: Turpi nempe nota res est, per secula nota.
app.rdg: This foul deed, which has been passed down through the centuries, is certainly infamous.

app.lem: Quis non horrescat, quis non horrenda pauescat,
app.rdg: After all, who does not shrink in horror, and fear this repulsive act?

app.lem: Dum contra legem nature, faemina regem,
app.rdg: That a woman, against the law of nature, should spurn a king

app.lem: Regem formosum, prudentem, deliciosum
app.rdg: – and no mere king, but handsome, prudent, and pleasant –

app.lem: Despicit, atque fere succumbit plus muliere?
app.rdg: only to have sex with a wild beast!

app.lem: Femina, res fragilis, precio conducta monilis
app.rdg: Woman, a fragile creature, bribed with the price of a necklace,

app.lem: In populo Danaum, male prodidit Amphiaraum.
app.rdg:
betrayed Amphiaraus to the Greek people.
Eriphyle, Amphiaraus’ wife, persuaded him to join a fatal raid. See Ps.-Apollodorus Bibliotheca 3.8.2.

app.lem: Sic quoque priuignum uita non funere dignum,

app.rdg: Thus also did Phaedra betray Hippolytus, whom she desired unjustly,

app.lem: Usque renitentem patriumque cubile uerentem,

app.rdg: and who was worthy of life and not of death,

app.lem: Prodidit Ypolitum, contra ius Phedra cupitum.

app.rdg:
all because he showed reverence for his father’s bed by resisting her advances.
Cf., among others, Euripides’ Hippolytus.

app.lem: Naso suis libris inscribit quomodo Biblis
app.rdg: Similarly, Naso writes in his books about how Biblis

app.lem: Igne sit illicito male saucia fratre cupito.
app.rdg:
Was badly burnt by an illicit flame while she lusted after her brother.
Ov. Met. 9.

app.lem: Fraude quidem mira Cynare coiit sua Myrra,
app.rdg: Deceived in an astounding manner, Cinyras slept with his daughter,

app.lem:
Inque loco [matris] concepit semine [patris].
BnF Ms. Lat. 16699, f. 176v reads: ‘Inque loco patris concepit semine matris.’ However this is illogical and likely the result of scribal error. My reading is supported by the critical edition, Van Acker, L. (ed.) (1972). Petri Pictoris Carmina. Nec Non Petri de Sancto Audemaro Librum de Coloribus Faciendis. CCCM 25. Turnhout (Brepols): 103-116, which is mainly derived from BnF Ms. Lat. 13768.
app.rdg:
who, taking her mother’s place, conceived by the seed of her father.
Ibid., 10.300ff. Cinyras’ daughter was named Myrrha.

app.lem: Scilla patri Niso, fatali crine reciso,
Pretulit externum regem, regnumque paternum,
app.rdg: she handed her father’s kingdom over to you,

app.lem: Moinos, concedit tibi, dum fieri tua credit,
app.rdg: as she believed that she would be yours.

app.lem: Sed detestatus tam diri monstra reatus,
app.rdg: However, detesting the portents of such a dreadful deed,

app.lem: Et scelus et Scillam metuens, fugis hoc fugis illam.
app.rdg:
you avoid both Scylla and her crime, fearing them both.
The abrupt shift to second-person from the original third-person omniscient viewpoint is noteworthy; in so doing, Petrus Pictor does not only address Minos, Scylla’s love interest, but also involves the reader. He therefore rounds off his long invective against women, which has been building up in an increasingly emotional crescendo, by breaking the fourth wall. Moreover, lines 90 to 94 are especially noteworthy as they include a sliding scale of tenses – the ablative absolute (reciso, ‘having cut off’) gives way to the perfect indicative (pretulit...credit, ‘preferred...believed’), and then to a perfect participle (detestatus, ‘detesting’), which in turn yields to a present participle (metuens, ‘fearing’), culminating finally in the present indicative (fugis, ‘you avoid’). This gradual rise from the past into the present parallels the aforementioned shift in perspective, and underscores Petrus Pictor’s message about the constant danger which women pose. He suggests that his warnings should not be dismissed as historical and biblical examples from the distant past, but as mere ‘precursors’ (line 29, portenta) to female wickedness in the reader’s present life.
